subject: Remove locks from Pure volume drivers
commit_message:
Remove locks from Pure volume drivers

If we switch to using a retry and are more careful about handling errors
when a host is deleted or volumes are attached we don’t need to use the
lock.

For initialize_connection time when we go to create a host we run the
risk that a terminate_connection running in parallel deleted our host
from underneath us before the volume was attached. To handle that we
just catch the error in that scenario and try to create the host again.

The second issue for initialize_connection is if we try to create a host
and another initialize_connection running in parallel beats us to it. If
the host already exists we can catch the exception for create_host(..)
and retry, which will give us the existing one.

For terminate_connection time we run the risk that between when we
determine a host to be ready for deletion and actually deleting it a
new volume is attached. We can just swallow this error since the Purity
management API will not allow to delete a host with connected volumes.

Change-Id: I8ae75dab279bb983a31595b6af6105a933d5c72c
Closes-Bug: #1588089

Add new `show_multiple_failures` to Workflow class (defaults to `True`
which is consistent with current behavior). In case it is `False`, any
additional messages generated for the recoverable errors (raised
inside the methods called by `workflow.handle()`) will be discarded
and only the message specified at `workflow.failure_message` will be
displayed. In case non-recoverable error is raised,
`show_multiple_failures` has no effect, because
`workflow.failure_message` is not shown then and there isn't single
point of authority high enough on the callstack to decide which
messages should be shown and which should not.

Closes-Bug: #1301374

nova::compute::libvirt was a class that deployed both libvirt (+
external services related to it) and nova-compute bits (mainly
configuration).

In the micro-services use-case, we want individual services, that can
run alone in containers. To allow it, we need to split the nova compute
configuration when libvirt is configured and the libvirt deployment.

This patch aims to create nova::compute::libvirt::services that contain
the bits from nova::compute::libvirt that used to deploy Libvirt and
some other packages / services related to it.

We keep backward compatibility by declaring the new class in
nova::compute::libvirt but allow to disable it and select what we
actually need thanks to parameters (we support hiera & non-hiera, see
code for comments that document it).

This is a first iteration of micro services for Compute nodes, soon

subject: Support new style (and multiple) external networks
commit_message:
Support new style (and multiple) external networks

Switch the generated configuration to use "new" style external
networks when ext-port is not set.  In this case we configure
external_network_bridge = (intentionally blank),
gateway_external_network_id = (blank) and update the README with
information on using this new style of configuration.

The current template configures external networks by using the default
external_network_bridge=br-ex (implied when not set).  This activates
legacy code which assumes that a single external network exists on
that bridge and the L3 Agent directly plugs itself in.
provider:network_type, provider:physical_network and
provider:segmentation_id are ignored.  You cannot create multiple
networks and you cannot use segmented networks (e.g. VLAN)

By setting external_network_bridge = (intentionally blank) the L2
Agent handles the configuration instead, this allows us to create
multiple networks and also to use more complex network configurations
such as VLAN.  It is also possible to use the same physical connection
with different segmentation IDs for both internal and external
networks, as well as multiple external networks.

Legacy/existing configurations where ext-port is set generate the same
configuration as previous and should continue to work as before.  I do
not believe it to be easy to migrate existing setups to the "new"
style configuration automatically as changes to the neutron network
configuration may be required (specifically: provider:physical_network
will now be used when it was not before, and may not be correct) and
the physical port needs to be moved from br-ex to br-data which the
charm does not currently handle and is likely to error as it does not
attempt removal first.  Further work may be possible in this area.

For information about this new style of configuration being preferred,
see discussions in LP#1491668, LP#1525059 and
http://docs.openstack.org/liberty/networking-guide/scenario-classic-ovs.html

Change-Id: I8d2bb8098e080969e0445293b1ed79714b2c964f

Related-Bug: #1525059
Closes-Bug: #1536768

ganesha: implement update_access

As with Ganesha there is no direct way to

we just call down to the old allow/deny methods

and normal mode, and also setting the recovery_mode flag
appropriately). The driver is also responsible for checking
the validity of the rules, for which we add support
by the NASHelperBase

  supported_access_levels

subject: WIP Simple Cache Service
commit_message:
WIP Simple Cache Service

When a user takes action on a resource, a view may not have the
updated item for a few seconds, however it is important
that the UI remember that the item is "in-progress" so that it can
give a visual clue to the user that their action had an effect.

This simple cache service is intended to be used like this:
1) View offers an action on an item.
2) User clicks action
3) Immediately when action returns, view "adds" the item to the cache
   with a timestamp that indicates when the resource was last updated.
   This timestamp may be server time, or client time, depending on the
   needs of the view.
4) The view can use "inCache" for each item to decide if the item needs
   to be marked as "in-progress" for the user.  Any item that is in
   the cache may be inconsistent with the service side until the next
   "sync"
5) When the view next gets a full list of resource items (perhaps from
   polling) it calls cache "sync" on each item with the appropriate
   timestamp for each newly fetched item (again, possibly using server
   time for the most recent fetch).

   If "sync" finds the item in the cache with a newer timestamp, it
   returns it. This means the client hasn't gotten an updated version
   since the user's action.

   If "sync" finds the item in the cache, but it has an older timestamp
   the new item is preferred, and the old item is cleared from the cache.

   In both cases, the caller should always use the item returned by "sync"
   so that the cache can substitute cached items when necessary.
6) Periodically, call "clean" to clean out items older than some
   maximum age (perhaps 2X the polling period).
   
   NOTE: The "age" of an item in the cache is the client time differnce
   from when it was added. The 'timestamp' on the other hand, is a value
   that indicates when the item was last fetched from the service and
   may be server time, client time, or some other counter.

Partially-Implements: blueprint searchlight-search-panel

subject: WIP Proof of concept for actions returning promises
commit_message:
WIP Proof of concept for actions returning promises

This is a test of actions returning a standard promise to allow
a view to act on arbitrary actions without knowledge of the meaning
of that action...or what kind of interface the action uses.

It can then tell which items were successfully acted upon. In cases
where the action doesn't return the updated data...the view can
simply indicate the item is "in-progress" and  will be updated
whenever the view chooses to refresh its list of data)

This now modified the "actions" directive to allow the view controller
to pass a promise handler that the action should return the promise
to.

To use:
1) Create an image as an admin.
2) Go to /project/ngimages
3) Select an image (or set of images) to delete. You can select
   a mix of images that you are allowed, or not, to delete.
4) Hit the "Delete Images" button.
5) The console logs the action result and the image is removed from
   the table

Notice that the view doesn't need to know that the user just clicked
a "delete" action. Instead, the action returns a standard promise,
with standard data, that the view can use to update "created",
"deleted", "updated" or "failed" items. This allows the view to be
able to handle almost any future action available for images, with no
additional changes.

Notice also that the event dispatched by the delete image action is no
longer used by the view, instead, when the modal resolves its promise
the view takes action with the acted upon items (deleting them from
the table in this case...but in general all it would know is that
the item is "in-progress" and a data refresh may be needed.

Of particular interest is the new proposed structure to hold
resource related actions and views. Resource types follow the heat
